awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Increasing Catalytic Selectivity for Isomerization of Glucose to Fructose using Paired Lewis Acid Sites
awd_abstract_narration:
The study targets design of heterogeneous catalysts for the liquid-phase isomerization of glucose to fructose, a key step in the valorization of biomass to chemicals and fuels. The authors utilize a bio-inspired catalyst design approach that has the potential to reduce cost of bio-renewable processing, increasing the economic competitiveness with fossil fuel sources of bio-derived chemicals and fuels. Integrated into the catalyst design approach is an educational outreach program that will increase participation of women and underrepresented minorities in STEM fields.

Specifically, the PI seeks to synthesize catalytic materials containing well-defined paired catalytic sites on a solid silica support to increase the catalytic activity and selectivity for the isomerization of glucose to fructose. The paired site design utilizes a bio-inspired approach, translating the paired catalytic site of enzymes into a heterogeneous catalytic material. The proposed work will focus on developing a hydrothermal synthesis method that will incorporate paired sites into the zeolite framework. The work will seek to tune the catalytic performance through changing the composition of the pairs to demonstrate the mechanistic impact of paired sites. The study will also develop advanced spectroscopic methods to help identify the formation of paired catalytic sites. The technological impact of the project can be substantial since it will add a new dimension to the ability to tune catalytic performance and provide a method to increase the selectivity for biomass conversion to fructose and decrease associated energy costs. Overall, this would create a more economically viable route than currently available to produce high fructose corn syrup, biomass-derived polymers, or commodity chemicals. The work will be performed by a diverse team of students that will be trained in advanced catalytic material synthesis and testing. In addition to undergraduate and graduate education opportunities, the project will interface with several existing programs at Ohio State University to create a classroom module for students and a project to introduce the concepts of size-selective separation of zeolitic materials ? a critical feature of these materials ? to elementary school children to inspire future generations to pursue education in STEM-related fields. The filtration module will be made available through the PI website to expand the impact of the outreach efforts.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Our research has investigated the synthesis and design of Lewis acid zeolites. The discoveries have elucidated underlying phenomena that will be important for a range of chemical reactions. We are adding key details that will help us understand how to make more active and selective catalysts. The catalyst designs are adding to our toolbox so that we can tackle future challenges. These results have been broadly shared through a combination of publications, presentations, and community outreach activities organized by the group, including incorporating the outcomes of the research into classroom discussions and assignments.

The specific research advances include the development of a method capable of producing paired tin atoms as the catalytic site that was submitted for patenting. These studies inspired us to examine a range of chemistry, including the alcohol ring opening of epoxides. Using this reaction, we were able to demonstrate how tuning the particle size to create nano-zeolites enabled us to overcome limitations with product diffusion. We expanded the synthesis of Lewis acid nano-zeolite with the Beta structure. Whereas the nano-zeolites could overcome product diffusion limitations, the activity of the material was impacted by the material hydrophobicity. We tuned the hydrophobicity to demonstrate that hydrophobic reaction environments are beneficial for achieving high activity. With synthetic methods established, we have been using these techniques to produce zeolites with tailored properties and to investigate synthesis-structure-function behavior. We have connected spectroscopic experiments with investigation of the different catalytic species present in the materials to reveal the nature of highly active sites. Through modifying the site precursor, we are able to create highly active catalytic sites that will be broadly applicable to a wide range of catalytic reactions.

The work also provided research opportunities for undergraduate students. The students have been very active with developing new synthesis methods to improve the tunability of zeolite catalysts. The students have contributed to publications and pursued graduate education to further advance catalytic capabilities.

The project has also supported several graduate students as they have matriculated through the program. They have received strong technical training as well as mentoring and professional development so that the students are prepared to tackle future challenges in catalyst development. This includes collaborative work that combines experiment and theory that will be beneficial for tackling complex challenges that require a multi-discipinary approach.

Combined, these studies helped advance our synthetic capabilities to produce Lewis acid zeolites and investigate structure-function properties. The insights revealed have the potential to re-define our understanding of the catalytic site and enable the production of fine chemicals. These experiences have provided the necessary skill to build a highly skilled workforce.


Last Modified: 06/30/2023
Modified by: Nicholas A Brunelli
